instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820-2915 power cycling
threads.message: 820-2915 seems to be power cycling. I get bursts of the S3 and S0 rails. SMC_PM_G2_EN and P3V3S5_EN cycles high-low. Can't find any shorts or heat on the board. PPVRTC_G3H also seems to be cycling, but between 3.3-3.4v only.

threads.title: 820-2915 power cycling
threads.message: Came from another shop, so not much. Looks clean, no noticeable liquid. PPBUS_G3H is steady 12.5v.

threads.title: 820-2915 power cycling
threads.message: G2_EN will cycle when S5_PWRGD does not come high, but could be many other things. BIOS, clk chip, too. CPU Vcore coming on?

threads.title: 820-2915 power cycling
threads.message: S5_PWRGD is cycling high-low. I don't get CPU vcore. It's about 7 ohms to ground, doesn't seem like a short but don't have a good board to compare to.

threads.title: 820-2915 power cycling
threads.message: No ALL_SYS_PWRGD, and PP3V3_S0 isn't coming on all the way (less than 1v).

threads.title: 820-2915 power cycling
threads.message: Q7812 doesn't seem to have anything on its gates, but Q7830 does cycle to 0v on its gate.

threads.title: 820-2915 power cycling
threads.message: 3v3_s0 is needed to enable ALL_SYS, check why 3v3_s0 is not coming high.

threads.title: 820-2915 power cycling
threads.message: Beat you to it :) see above.

threads.title: 820-2915 power cycling
threads.message:
[QUOTE="arghhh, post: 12032"]Q7812 doesn't seem to have anything on its gates, but Q7830 does cycle to 0v on its gate.[/QUOTE]

This is not possible. Q7830 gate can only be pulled low if PM_SLP_S3_R_L is present which goes straight to Q7812 gate.

threads.title: 820-2915 power cycling
threads.message: I know, I thought the same thing but I'm really not getting anything. It's possible that my multimeter is just too slow to pick it up, but I don't have an oscilloscope.

threads.title: 820-2915 power cycling
threads.message: Well, if you give me measurements that don't make sense there is nothing I can do.
